data.text: Neither warm nor very cold; moderately cold.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: fresh, cool water; a cool autumn evening.

data.text: Giving or suggesting relief from heat.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: a cool breeze; a cool blouse.

data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Marked by indifference, disdain, or dislike; unfriendly or unresponsive.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: a cool greeting; was cool to the idea of higher taxes.

data.text: Of, relating to, or characteristic of colors, such as blue and green, that produce the impression of coolness.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Knowledgeable or aware of the latest trends or developments.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: spent all his time trying to be cool.

data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: has a cool sports car; had a cool time at the party.

data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: It's cool if you don't want to talk about it.

data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
